recipes.name: Indo-German Spinach Vegetable Curry
ingredients: 350 grams mixed frozen vegetables (carrot, peas, corn, cauliflower, and beans)
1 bunch fresh spinach, washed and chopped
directions: Step 1: Prepare the spinach. If using frozen spinach, place it in a ceramic plate and microwave for 2 minutes until slightly softened. Alternatively, heat in a nonstick pan for 5 minutes. If using fresh spinach, wash and chop it finely, boil for 10 minutes in a little water, then cool to room temperature and grind to a semi-solid state.

Step 2: Prepare the vegetables. If using frozen mixed vegetables, microwave according to package instructions for 2-3 minutes. For fresh vegetables, chop the carrot and cauliflower. Heat 1 teaspoon of vegetable oil in a pan, add the chopped vegetables, fry for 1 minute, and cover the pan to cook for an additional 2 minutes.

Step 3: Temper the spices. In a nonstick pan, heat 2 teaspoons of oil over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and asafoetida, and when the seeds begin to pop, add the chopped onions, ginger, and garlic. Fry until the onions turn golden brown while adding a pinch of salt to expedite cooking.
Step 4: Add the spices. Mix in red chili powder and coriander powder, and cook until the raw smell dissipates.

Step 5: Incorporate the vegetables. If using frozen butter vegetables, add them and cook for 5 minutes. If using fresh vegetables, add them and cook for 5 minutes. Then, mix in the prepared spinach puree and season with salt. Reduce the heat and simmer for 10 minutes until the vegetables are thoroughly cooked.

Step 6: Combine the spinach and yogurt. Once the vegetables are cooked, stir in the chopped spinach from Step 1 and cook for a few more minutes. Then, reduce the heat and add the whisked yogurt, mixing well. Cook for another 2 minutes.
Step 7: Serve the curry hot with rice, chapati, or paratha. Enjoy this unique Indo-German dish!
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant bowl of Indo-German Spinach Vegetable Curry, styled with a rustic wooden table backdrop. Use natural light to enhance the rich green hues of the spinach and the colorful mixed vegetables, creating a warm and inviting atmosphere. Garnish with fresh cilantro and a sprinkle of chili flakes for contrast. Shoot from a slightly elevated angle to emphasize the dish's depth, with a shallow depth of field to blur the background, drawing focus to the curry’s texture. Use a simple white plate for elegance, complemented by a wooden spoon and a small bowl of rice on the side.

scenes.text: Step 6: Combine the spinach and yogurt.
scenes.voice_over: Once vegetables are cooked, stir in the chopped spinach and whisked yogurt, cooking for another 2 minutes.

Adjust spice levels according to your taste preference.

recipes.name: Aloo Broccoli Sabzi (Broccoli Potato Fry)
ingredients: 400 grams fresh broccoli, cut into small florets
4 medium-sized potatoes, sliced into lengthy pieces
2 tablespoons vegetable oil for frying and tempering
directions: Step 1: Slice the potatoes into lengthy pieces and set aside.
Step 2: Cut the broccoli into small florets and set aside.

Step 3: Heat 1 tablespoon of vegetable oil in a nonstick pan, add the sliced potatoes and a pinch of salt. Fry for 5 minutes until they are partially cooked. Transfer the potatoes to a bowl and cover them.

Step 4: In the same pan, heat another tablespoon of vegetable oil, add the broccoli florets with a pinch of salt. Fry for 5 minutes until they are partially cooked. Transfer the broccoli to the bowl with the potatoes and cover.

Step 5: Heat 2 tablespoons of vegetable oil in a pan for tempering. Add cumin seeds and chopped onions. Sauté until the onions turn golden. Then, add grated garlic and continue to cook until the raw smell disappears.
Step 6: Add the chopped tomatoes to the onion mixture and cook until they are fully mashed. Stir in the turmeric, coriander powder, and chili powder. Mix well.

Step 7: Add the partially cooked potatoes and broccoli to the spice mixture. Cover the pan and cook on high flame for 5 minutes, then sprinkle garam masala, reduce heat, and cook for an additional 5 minutes until tender.
Step 8: Finally, add lime juice, stir for 2 more minutes, then remove from heat. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves before serving.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant Aloo Broccoli Sabzi in a rustic wooden bowl, emphasizing the lush green broccoli and golden potato slices against a textured dark slate background. Use natural soft lighting to illuminate the dish, highlighting the spices' vibrant colors. Incorporate a sprinkle of fresh cilantro and a lemon wedge for contrast. Shoot from a 45-degree angle to create depth, with a shallow depth of field that softly blurs the background, drawing focus to the dish's enticing textures and rich hues.

video_script.title: Aloo Broccoli Sabzi (Broccoli Potato Fry) Recipe
video_script.description: Learn how to make a delicious Aloo Broccoli Sabzi featuring a blend of spices and fresh vegetables. Perfect as a side dish or a main meal!

scenes.image_prompt: Broccoli florets being added to the same pan with oil, sizzling as they cook.
scenes.voice_over: Now, in the same pan, add another tablespoon of oil and toss in the broccoli florets with a pinch of salt. Fry for another 5 minutes until partially cooked.

scenes.image_prompt: Onions sizzling in a pan, with garlic being grated over them, creating a flavorful aroma.
scenes.voice_over: Using the same pan, heat 2 tablespoons of oil for tempering. Add cumin seeds and chopped onions. Sauté until the onions turn golden. Then mix in the grated garlic until fragrant.

scenes.image_prompt: Chopped tomatoes being stirred into the frying onions, a brightly colored mixture sizzling in the pan.
scenes.voice_over: Add in the chopped tomatoes and cook until they're fully mashed. Stir in turmeric, coriander powder, and chili powder.

scenes.image_prompt: Potatoes and broccoli being combined into the spice mixture with a lid on the pan.
scenes.voice_over: Now, add the partially cooked potatoes and broccoli to the spice blend. Cover and cook on high for 5 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: Sprinkling garam masala over the cooking vegetables in the pan, followed by a vibrant mixture of colors.
scenes.voice_over: Sprinkle in the garam masala, lower the heat, and cook for another 5 minutes until everything is tender.

scenes.image_prompt: Final dish being plated, lime juice being drizzled over the sabzi with fresh coriander for garnishing.
scenes.voice_over: Finish by adding a splash of lime juice. Stir for 2 more minutes, then remove from heat and garnish with fresh coriander.

scenes.voice_over: And here you have it! Aloo Broccoli Sabzi, ready to be enjoyed with rice or naan. Bon appétit!

cooking_tips: For extra flavor, consider adding a pinch of asafoetida (hing) while tempering.
Ensure the vegetables do not overcook to maintain a slight crunch.

recipes.name: Capsicum and Broccoli Besan Stir-Fry Sabzi
ingredients: 1/2 teaspoon fresh Lime or Lemon Juice
directions: Step 1: Wash and chop the Capsicum and Broccoli into medium-sized pieces, removing any seeds from the Capsicum.
Step 2: In a non-stick pan, dry roast 3 tablespoons of Besan on low flame while stirring continuously to prevent lumps.
Step 3: Once the Besan turns golden, add 1/2 teaspoon of Asafoetida, 1 teaspoon of Cumin Powder, and 1 teaspoon of Coriander Powder. Stir continuously until the mixture is aromatic.
Step 4: Mix in 1 teaspoon of Red Chili Powder to the Besan. Remove from heat and transfer to a plate.
Step 5: Heat 5 tablespoons of Cooking Oil in the same non-stick pan. Once hot, add 1 teaspoon of Cumin Seeds, 1/2 teaspoon of Asafoetida, and 1/4 teaspoon of Turmeric Powder.

Step 6: When the raw flavor of Turmeric dissipates, add the chopped Broccoli and season with Salt. Cook until the Broccoli is partially cooked, then add the chopped Capsicum. Cover and cook on low flame until soft, stirring occasionally.
Step 7: Once the Capsicum is cooked, drizzle with 1/2 teaspoon of fresh Lime or Lemon Juice and mix well.
Step 8: Gradually spread the roasted Besan mixture over the vegetables. Cover and cook for an additional 2 minutes, then gently mix to combine.
Step 9: Continue cooking for another 5 minutes on low heat, stirring occasionally to combine the flavors.
Step 10: Garnish the dish with chopped Coriander Leaves before serving.
Step 11: Serve the Capsicum and Broccoli Besan Stir-Fry Sabzi with rice or chapatti.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant Capsicum and Broccoli Besan Stir-Fry Sabzi in a shallow, white ceramic bowl placed on a rustic wooden surface. Use natural light from the left to enhance the glossy textures of the roasted besan and the vivid colors of the vegetables. Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves and a sprinkle of red chili powder on top. Shoot from a 45-degree angle to showcase the dish's depth, with a soft focus on the background to create a warm, inviting mood.

recipes.name: Beetroot and Broccoli Stir-Fry
directions: Step 1: Heat 1/2 teaspoon of oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the broccoli florets along with salt. Cover the pan and steam the broccoli for approximately 6 minutes until tender. Remove the broccoli and set it aside.

Step 2: In a pressure cooker, add diced beetroot with salt and a little water. Cook under pressure for 2 whistles. Release the pressure, then separate the beetroot pieces from the water and set both aside.
Step 3: In a non-stick pan, heat 1 teaspoon of oil. Add mustard seeds and allow them to pop. Then, add minced garlic, cumin seeds, chana dal, urad dal, and curry leaves, sautéing until fragrant.
Step 4: Add the chopped onion to the tempering. Sauté until the onions turn golden brown. Then mix in turmeric powder, red chili powder, and garam masala, stirring well to combine.
Step 5: Incorporate the cooked beetroot pieces into the pan with the spices and sauté on low flame for 2 minutes.
Step 6: Add the previously steamed broccoli to the sautéed mixture and gently mix all the ingredients together. Cover the pan and continue to cook for 1 minute.

Step 7: Sprinkle besan (gram flour) over the vegetables. Pour in the reserved beetroot water and mix well. Cover the pan and cook until the mixture thickens, adjusting the consistency as needed. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant Beetroot and Broccoli Stir-Fry, artfully arranged in a rustic white bowl, against a textured wooden surface. Use natural light to illuminate the dish, enhancing the rich purples of beetroot and the fresh greens of broccoli. Incorporate a sprinkle of sesame seeds and fresh cilantro as garnishes. Position the camera at a 45-degree angle for dynamic layering, with a shallow depth of field to softly blur the background, allowing the dish to be the focal point, evoking a warm, inviting mood.

recipes.name: Paneer Masala – Indian Fresh Cheese Curry
ingredients: 1 bunch fresh coriander leaves, chopped for garnish
directions: Step 1: Heat 1 teaspoon of vegetable oil in a pan over medium heat. Add 1 cup of cubed paneer and fry until golden brown. Transfer the fried paneer to a bowl and set aside. Grate the remaining 1 cup of paneer.

Step 2: In the same pan, heat another teaspoon of oil and add the cloves, cumin seeds, and cinnamon sticks. Sauté until fragrant, then remove from heat and grind the mixture to a fine powder. Set aside for later use.

Step 3: In a separate pan, heat 1 teaspoon of oil; add the chopped onions and tomatoes along with the ginger-garlic paste. Cook for a few minutes until softened. Transfer this mixture to a blender and blitz into a fine paste.

Step 4: In the same frying pan, heat 5 teaspoons of butter. Add the cashews, coriander powder, garam masala, salt, chili powder, and the ground masala powder from Step 2. Stir-fry until aromatic, then incorporate the paste from Step 3.

Step 5: Continue to fry until the raw flavor dissipates, then add the yogurt to the mixture. Mix thoroughly until the gravy thickens. Once thick, gently fold in the fried paneer cubes and grated paneer. Add 1 cup of water, cover, and simmer on low heat for 10 minutes, allowing the gravy to absorb into the paneer.
Step 6: Garnish the Paneer Masala with chopped fresh coriander leaves before serving.

Use natural light from the side to enhance the rich colors of the curry, creating soft shadows that highlight the paneer cubes. Position a colorful Indian textile beneath the dish for warmth, and shoot from a slightly elevated angle to showcase the creamy sauce. Use a shallow depth of field to blur the background, keeping the focus on the glossy paneer and inviting garnishes, evoking a cozy, inviting mood.

recipes.name: Chana Chole Masala - Spicy Chickpeas Curry
directions: Step 1: Drain the soaked chickpeas and set them aside for cooking.

Step 2: Heat oil in a non-stick pan over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and wait for them to pop. Then add black cumin seeds, cumin seeds, ajwain, curry leaves, bay leaf, and ginger-garlic paste. Sauté for a few minutes until fragrant.
Step 3: Add chopped onions to the pan and fry until they turn golden brown.
Step 4: Stir in the chopped tomatoes and tomato puree. Cook until the tomatoes soften and the oil separates from the mixture, forming a thick gravy.
Step 5: Add turmeric powder, coriander powder, and red chili powder. Mix well and cook for a few minutes until the raw flavors diminish.

Step 6: Introduce the soaked chickpeas into the pan and mix with the gravy. Cook for about 10 minutes, adding a little water if necessary, or transfer the mixture to a pressure cooker. Cook under pressure for 3 whistles.
Step 7: Soak tamarind in warm water for 30 minutes, then extract the juice. Mix the tamarind juice with plain flour or corn flakes, and add it to the cooking curry to thicken the gravy.
Step 8: When the curry thickens, remove it from heat. Sprinkle in the garam masala and stir well.
Step 9: Garnish the curry with finely chopped fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with chapati, naan, roti, paratha, or bhatura.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant bowl of Chana Chole Masala, filled with rich, spicy chickpeas curry, topped with fresh cilantro and a sprinkle of red chili powder for color. Use a rustic wooden table as your background, with a textured linen napkin and a small dish of naan nearby. Opt for soft, natural lighting to enhance the dish’s warm hues and glossy textures. Shoot from a slightly overhead angle to showcase the curry’s depth, with a shallow depth of field to blur the background, creating a cozy, inviting mood.

scenes.voice_over: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot with chapati, naan, or rice. Enjoy your meal!

scenes.voice_over: That's it! You've made a hearty Chana Chole Masala. It’s nutritious and delicious. Happy cooking!

cooking_tips: For best flavor, use freshly ground spices.
Adjust the amount of chili powder according to your heat preference.
You can use canned chickpeas to save time; just skip the soaking step.

recipes.name: Spicy Maida Diamond Cut Biscuits - Indian Snack
ingredients: Water, as needed to prepare dough
directions: Step 1: In a large mixing bowl, combine the wheat flour, rice flour, besan, salt, red chili powder, sesame seeds, and cumin seeds. Mix thoroughly.

Step 2: Gradually add water as needed and knead until the dough is soft. Incorporate 2 tablespoons of oil or ghee while kneading. Taste and adjust salt and spices as necessary. Allow the dough to rest for 5 minutes.
Step 3: Divide the dough into lemon-sized balls and roll them out into slightly thick chapati-like discs.
Step 4: Create small holes using a fork or knife on the rolled dough. Cut the dough into square or diamond shapes using a sharp knife to form raw diamond chips.

Step 5: Heat sufficient oil in a deep pan over high heat. Once the oil is hot, carefully drop in the diamond shapes. Fry until they rise to the surface, then reduce the heat and continue frying until they turn golden brown.
Step 6: Remove the biscuits using a slotted spoon and place them on kitchen paper to absorb excess oil. Allow them to cool completely before storing in an airtight container to maintain crispiness.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up shot of Spicy Maida Diamond Cut Biscuits arranged artfully on a rustic wooden board, garnished with a sprinkle of sesame seeds and a few ajwain seeds for texture. Use soft, diffused natural light to enhance the golden hues and crispy textures of the biscuits. Include a small bowl of spicy dipping sauce beside them, and a few scattered whole spices for added visual interest. Employ a shallow depth of field to keep the focus on the biscuits, creating a warm, inviting mood that evokes a sense of homemade comfort.

video_script.title: Spicy Maida Diamond Cut Biscuits - Indian Snack
video_script.description: Learn how to make crispy and spicy maida diamond cut biscuits, a delicious Indian snack perfect for tea time!

scenes.voice_over: You'll need wheat flour, rice flour, besan, carom seeds, cumin seeds, red chili powder, sesame seeds, hing, salt, and oil for frying.

scenes.voice_over: In a mixing bowl, combine 1 cup each of wheat flour and rice flour, 1/2 cup of besan, along with salt, red chili powder, sesame seeds, and cumin seeds. Mix well.

scenes.image_prompt: Hands kneading a soft dough in a bowl, with a small container of water and oil nearby.
scenes.voice_over: Gradually add water to the mixture and knead until the dough is soft. Incorporate 2 tablespoons of oil while kneading. Let it rest for 5 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: Scene showing round balls of dough being flattened with a rolling pin on a countertop.
scenes.voice_over: Divide the dough into lemon-sized balls and roll each out into slightly thick discs resembling chapatis.

scenes.image_prompt: A close-up of a fork making holes in the rolled dough and cutting it into diamond shapes.
scenes.voice_over: Using a fork, create small holes in the rolled dough, then cut it into diamond shapes with a sharp knife.

scenes.image_prompt: A deep pan with hot oil and diamond shapes frying, with bubbles around them.
scenes.voice_over: Heat oil in a deep pan over high heat until hot. Drop the diamond shapes carefully, and fry until golden brown, adjusting the heat as necessary.

scenes.image_prompt: A slotted spoon lifting the fried biscuits from the oil, with a paper towel-lined plate in the background.
scenes.voice_over: Once golden, remove the biscuits with a slotted spoon and drain them on kitchen paper to absorb excess oil.

scenes.image_prompt: A final display of the crispy maida diamond cut biscuits in a decorative bowl, with a seasoning shaker and cup of tea in the background.
scenes.voice_over: Let the biscuits cool completely before storing in an airtight container. Enjoy them with your favorite tea!

cooking_tips: Ensure the oil is hot enough before frying to achieve a crispy texture.
Adjust the spices to suit your heat preference.
Store in an airtight container to preserve freshness.

recipes.name: Kidney Beans Curry (Rajma Masala)
ingredients: 1.5 cups kidney beans (Rajma), soaked for 5 hours or overnight
Chopped fresh coriander leaves, for garnish
directions: Step 1: Soak the kidney beans overnight or for 5 hours in water to reduce cooking time.

Step 2: Drain the soaked kidney beans and place them in a pressure cooker. Add salt and sufficient water. Cook for 3 whistles and allow the pressure to release naturally. Reserve the cooking liquid for later use.

Step 3: In a grinder, blend the garlic and ginger into a coarse paste. Heat 1 teaspoon of oil in a nonstick pan over medium heat. Add the mustard seeds and wait for them to splutter. Add the curry leaves and the ginger-garlic paste. Sauté until the raw aroma of ginger and garlic disappears.
Step 4: Add the chopped onions to the pan along with a pinch of salt. Sauté the onions until they turn golden brown, adjusting the cooking time based on the type of onion used.
Step 5: Incorporate the chopped tomatoes into the pan and cook until they are soft and blended into the gravy. The oil should begin to separate from the mixture.
Step 6: Add the coriander powder, red chili powder, garam masala, and chicken masala (if using) to the tomato-onion sauce. Stir well to combine until the spices become fragrant.

Step 7: Gently stir in the cooked kidney beans. Cover the pan and simmer for 2 minutes to let the beans absorb the spices. After 2 minutes, pour in the reserved kidney bean cooking liquid gradually and stir well. Allow the curry to cook for an additional 10 minutes.
Step 8: Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and stir gently before serving.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant bowl of Kidney Beans Curry (Rajma Masala) styled elegantly on a rustic wooden table. Use soft, diffused natural light to enhance the rich reds and earthy tones of the dish, emphasizing the textures of the kidney beans and the glistening sauce. Garnish with fresh cilantro and a sprinkle of garam masala. Frame the shot from a slight overhead angle, with a shallow depth of field to blur the background, creating a warm and inviting mood. Include a few colorful spices in small bowls and a woven cloth to add context and depth.

video_script.title: Delicious Kidney Beans Curry (Rajma Masala) Tutorial
video_script.description: Learn how to make a flavorful Kidney Beans Curry, known as Rajma Masala, with this step-by-step recipe tutorial.

scenes.text: Pressure cook kidney beans with salt.
scenes.voice_over: Drain the beans, add them to a pressure cooker with salt and enough water, and cook for three whistles.

scenes.voice_over: Gently stir in the cooked kidney beans, cover, and simmer for 10 minutes, adding reserved liquid to adjust consistency.

scenes.image_prompt: Fresh chopped coriander leaves being sprinkled on the finished curry in a vibrant pan.
scenes.voice_over: Finally, garnish with fresh coriander leaves before serving. Enjoy your Rajma Masala!

scenes.voice_over: Serve this flavorful curry with rice or naan for a complete meal. Bon appétit!

cooking_tips: For added creaminess, adjust the amount of coconut milk or cream as desired.
Serve with steamed rice or roti for a complete meal.
If you prefer a thicker curry, cook uncovered for a few additional minutes.

recipes.name: Cabbage and Carrot Stir-Fry
directions: Step 1: Heat 1 tablespoon of vegetable oil in a non-stick pan over medium heat. Add the shredded cabbage and grated carrot, cooking for a few minutes. Season with a pinch of salt, then cover the pan. Allow the vegetables to cook until the cabbage becomes tender and releases water, about 5 minutes. Transfer the mixture to a bowl and set aside.

Step 2: In the same pan, add another tablespoon of vegetable oil. Once hot, add mustard seeds and wait until they splutter. Add the urad dal, chana dal, and a pinch of asafoetida. Fry until the dals turn golden brown.
Step 3: Add the turmeric powder, chopped garlic, slit green chilies, and dried red chilies to the pan. Sauté until the garlic becomes fragrant and the raw smell dissipates.

Step 4: Stir in the curry leaves and garam masala, then add chopped onions (if desired) and continue to sauté until the onions turn golden brown. If using tomatoes, add them now and cook until they soften and break down.

Step 5: Return the cabbage and carrot mixture to the pan, combining everything well. Cook uncovered, stirring frequently, to allow any excess moisture to evaporate. Cook until both vegetables are tender but not mushy.
Step 6: Garnish the stir-fry with freshly chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot with chapati or rice. Enjoy your delicious Cabbage and Carrot Stir-Fry!
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant Cabbage and Carrot Stir-Fry in a shallow, rustic wooden bowl, showcasing the colorful textures of the shredded cabbage and grated carrot. Use natural light to create soft shadows, enhancing the freshness of the ingredients. Incorporate a dark slate background to contrast with the dish's bright colors. Include a sprinkle of fresh coriander on top for garnish and a few whole dried red chilies on the side. Focus on a shallow depth of field to draw attention to the stir-fry's intricate details, evoking a warm and inviting mood.

video_script.title: Delicious Cabbage and Carrot Stir-Fry Recipe

scenes.image_prompt: The same pan with mustard seeds popping and dals getting golden brown.
scenes.voice_over: In the same pan, add another tablespoon of oil and mustard seeds. Wait until they splutter, then add urad dal, chana dal, and a pinch of asafoetida. Fry until golden brown.

scenes.image_prompt: A pan filled with fragrant garlic, spices, and colorful chilies being sautéed.
scenes.voice_over: Add turmeric powder, chopped garlic, slit green chilies, and dried red chilies. Sauté until fragrant, allowing the raw smell of garlic to dissipate.

scenes.image_prompt: Curry leaves and garam masala being sprinkled into the pan, with optionally chopped onions and tomatoes.
scenes.voice_over: Next, add the curry leaves and garam masala. If you're using onions, toss them in now and sauté until golden brown. Optionally, add tomatoes and cook until softened.

scenes.image_prompt: The cabbage and carrot mixture being added back into the pan, with vibrant colors mixing.
scenes.voice_over: Return the cabbage and carrot mix to the pan, combining well. Cook uncovered, stirring frequently, until the vegetables are tender but not mushy.

scenes.image_prompt: The finished stir-fry garnished with fresh coriander leaves on a serving plate.
scenes.voice_over: Finish your stir-fry with freshly chopped coriander leaves. Serve it hot with chapati or rice for a delightful meal!

cooking_tips: Adjust the number of chilies based on your spice preference.
You can add other vegetables like bell peppers or peas for varied flavors.
Make sure not to overcook the cabbage to maintain its crunchy texture.

recipes.name: Aloo Gobi: Potato and Cauliflower Masala Curry
ingredients: 3 large potatoes, peeled and cut into medium-sized cubes
1/4 cup fresh coriander leaves, chopped (for garnish)
directions: Step 1: Prepare the potatoes and cauliflower by peeling the potatoes and cutting them into medium-sized cubes. Cut the cauliflower into large florets.
Step 2: Heat the cooking oil in a large saucepan over medium heat. Add the finely chopped onions and cumin seeds. Sauté until the onions become creamy, golden, and translucent.
Step 3: Incorporate the ginger and garlic paste into the onion mixture, stirring continuously until fragrant.
Step 4: Add the chopped tomatoes and cook until they soften and the mixture turns into a creamy sauce.
Step 5: Stir in the garam masala, coriander powder, chili powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix thoroughly.
Step 6: Add the prepared potatoes and cauliflower to the spiced mixture. Ensure the vegetables do not stick to the pan, adding a little water if necessary to coat them well with the sauce.
Step 7: Cover and cook on low heat until the potatoes are tender and cooked through, stirring occasionally.
Step 8: Turn off the heat and garnish the curry with freshly chopped coriander leaves before serving.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant Aloo Gobi curry in a rustic bowl, placing it atop a textured wooden table for warmth. Use natural light to accentuate the golden hues of turmeric and the earthy tones of potatoes and cauliflower. Style with a sprinkle of fresh coriander on top and a side of warm naan. Frame the shot from a 45-degree angle to emphasize depth, with a shallow depth of field blurring the background, creating a cozy, inviting mood. Incorporate a few scattered spices and a small copper pot for added authenticity.

scenes.voice_over: Add the prepared potatoes and cauliflower to the spiced mixture, coating them well. If necessary, add a splash of water.

scenes.voice_over: Cover and cook on low heat until the potatoes are tender, stirring occasionally, about 15-20 minutes.

recipes.name: Sweet Rice Pongal – Sakkarai Pongal
ingredients: 5 pieces jaggery, broken into small chunks
directions: Step 1: Rinse the rice thoroughly and soak it in water for 30 minutes.
Step 2: In a pressure cooker, add the soaked rice along with 3 cups of water. Cook on medium heat and release the pressure after 3 whistles, until the rice is soft and fully cooked.

Step 3: Rinse the moong dal under running water. In the same pressure cooker, add the rinsed dal and 3 cups of water. Cook for 3 whistles, then let the pressure release naturally until the dal is soft. Mash the dal lightly.

Step 4: For the jaggery syrup, break the jaggery into small pieces. In a saucepan, add the jaggery and ½ cup of water. Heat over medium flame, boiling for about 5 minutes or until the jaggery completely dissolves to form a light syrup.
Step 5: Filter the jaggery syrup through a sieve to remove any impurities. Taste and adjust sweetness by adding more jaggery or water if necessary.
Step 6: In a pan, heat 1 tablespoon of ghee over medium heat. Add the broken cashews, raisins, and crushed cardamom pods. Roast until the cashews turn golden brown and the raisins plump up.
Step 7: In a large mixing bowl, combine the cooked rice, mashed dal, and jaggery syrup. Mix well.
Step 8: Gradually add the milk to the mixture, stirring until well blended.
Step 9: Top the rice and dal mix with the roasted cashews, raisins, and cardamom for added flavor.
Step 10: Serve the delicious Sweet Rice Pongal warm, garnished with more cashews if desired.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a bowl of Sweet Rice Pongal, styled elegantly with a sprinkle of crushed cardamom and a few whole cashews on top. Use a warm, natural light source to enhance the creamy texture of the dish, creating soft shadows. Position the bowl slightly off-center on a rustic wooden table, surrounded by small brass bowls filled with jaggery and raisins. Use a shallow depth of field to keep the focus on the Pongal, while blurring the background for a cozy, inviting mood.

recipes.name: Raw Banana Stir Fry - Vazhakkai Podimas
ingredients: 2-3 medium-sized raw plantains, peeled and cut into large pieces
directions: Step 1: Peel the plantains and cut them into large pieces (halves or quarters).
Step 2: In a pressure cooker, boil the cut plantains with a little turmeric powder and salt for 5-10 minutes, until tender.
Step 3: Once cooked, drain and mash the plantains slightly, then set aside.
Step 4: In a non-stick pan, heat 2 tablespoons of vegetable oil over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and let them crackle.
Step 5: Add urad dal, chana dal, hing, turmeric powder, curry leaves, green chilies, and grated ginger to the pan. Stir-fry until the mixture turns light brown and aromatic.
Step 6: Add the lemon juice and salt to the pan along with the mashed plantains. Mix thoroughly to combine all ingredients well.

Use natural light to accentuate the yellows and greens, casting soft shadows to enhance textures. Style with fresh coriander leaves scattered around and a small bowl of chutney on the side. Include a textured linen napkin beneath the bowl for warmth. Shoot from a diagonal angle to emphasize the dish's depth, with a shallow depth of field to keep the focus on the colorful ingredients while softly blurring the background.

recipes.name: Raw Banana Bajji (Vazhakkai Bajji) - Plantain Fritters
ingredients: 1 raw banana (plantain), peeled and sliced thinly
A pinch of Eno salt (or baking soda)
A small pinch of hing powder (asafoetida)
directions: Step 1: Wash and clean the raw banana (also known as plantain or Vazhakkai). Apply a small amount of oil to your hands and knife before cutting to prevent stickiness. Peel off the outer layer and slice the banana longitudinally into thin pieces.
Step 2: In a mixing bowl, combine the besan, rice flour, barbecue masala, Eno salt, hing powder, and salt. Gradually add enough water to create a smooth batter.
Step 3: Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat until hot. Dip each banana slice in the batter and carefully slide them into the hot oil. Fry until the coating is golden brown and crispy.
Step 4: Remove the fritters from the oil and drain on kitchen paper to absorb excess oil. Serve hot with your choice of chutney or sauce.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up shot of golden-brown Raw Banana Bajji arranged artistically on a rustic wooden platter. Use a soft, diffused natural light to highlight the crispy texture and vibrant color of the fritters. Incorporate a small bowl of spicy dipping sauce and a sprinkle of fresh coriander for garnish. Position the camera at a 45-degree angle to emphasize the layers and detail. Use a shallow depth of field to blur the background, creating a warm, inviting mood that draws attention to the dish.

video_script.title: Delicious Raw Banana Bajji (Vazhakkai Bajji) - Plantain Fritters Recipe
video_script.description: Learn how to make crispy and flavorful Raw Banana Bajji, a delightful snack perfect for any occasion!

scenes.image_prompt: A beautifully plated serving of crispy Raw Banana Bajji fritters, garnished with fresh coriander and served with a side of spicy chutney.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome to our cooking channel! Today, we’ll be making delicious Raw Banana Bajji, a perfect crunchy snack for your evenings!

scenes.image_prompt: All the raw ingredients displayed: raw bananas, besan, rice flour, BBQ masala, Eno salt, hing powder, and oil for frying.
scenes.voice_over: For this recipe, we need raw bananas, besan, rice flour, BBQ masala, Eno salt, hing powder, and oil for frying.

scenes.image_prompt: A hand peeling and slicing a raw banana with a knife, surrounded by the mess of banana peels.
scenes.voice_over: Start by washing and peeling one raw banana. Slice it thinly and lengthwise to ensure crispiness.

scenes.image_prompt: A mixing bowl filled with besan, rice flour, BBQ masala, Eno salt, hing powder, and salt, alongside a whisk.
scenes.voice_over: In a mixing bowl, combine 150 grams of besan, 3 tablespoons of rice flour, 2 tablespoons of BBQ masala, a pinch of Eno salt, hing powder, and salt. Mix well.

scenes.image_prompt: A hand pouring water into the mixing bowl, whisking the ingredients together to form a batter.
scenes.voice_over: Gradually add water to create a smooth and thick batter. This will coat the banana slices evenly.

scenes.image_prompt: A deep frying pan with hot oil, and a hand carefully dipping banana slices into the batter.
scenes.voice_over: Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat until hot. Dip each banana slice in the batter and carefully fry them until golden brown.

scenes.image_prompt: Crispy fritters sizzling in hot oil, turning golden brown as they fry.
scenes.voice_over: Fry until the fritters are crispy and golden, about 3-4 minutes on each side.

scenes.image_prompt: A hand removing the fried bajjis from the oil, and placing them on kitchen paper to drain excess oil.
scenes.voice_over: Once fried, remove the Bajji from the oil and drain them on kitchen paper to absorb the excess oil.

scenes.image_prompt: A small plate served with crispy bajjis and various chutneys, ready to be enjoyed.
scenes.voice_over: Serve the hot Raw Banana Bajji with your favorite chutney. Enjoy this delicious snack while it's still warm!

cooking_tips: Ensure the oil is hot enough before adding the fritters to achieve a crispy texture.
You can add other spices to the batter for additional flavor.

recipes.name: Aloo Mattar: Spiced Potato and Green Peas Curry
ingredients: 4 medium potatoes, peeled and cut into quarters
1.5 cups fresh or frozen green peas
0.5 teaspoon red chili powder (adjust to taste)
directions: Step 1: Boil the quartered potatoes in a pressure cooker until the first whistle. Once done, cool them by adding cold water and then peel the skin.
Step 2: If using dried green peas, soak them for 5 hours, then cook in a pressure cooker until 3 whistles.
Step 3: Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the chopped onions and fry until golden brown.
Step 4: Add the chopped tomatoes to the pan and cook until they become mushy and fully integrated with the onions.
Step 5: Stir in the grated ginger, turmeric powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt. Cook for a few minutes until fragrant.
Step 6: Incorporate the cooked and peeled potatoes into the pan, stirring gently to combine, and add water if necessary to achieve desired consistency.
Step 7: Add the cooked green peas and mix carefully to avoid breaking the potatoes. Let the mixture simmer for a few minutes to blend the flavors.
Step 8: Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves and serve hot with roti, poori, chapati, or paratha.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant Aloo Mattar curry in a rustic, shallow bowl, showcasing the spiced potatoes and green peas with a glossy sheen. Use soft, natural light to enhance the rich colors of the dish, casting gentle shadows for depth. Arrange fresh coriander leaves as a garnish atop the curry, and place a few whole spices nearby for authenticity. Shoot from a 45-degree angle to highlight the texture, with a blurred earthy backdrop that complements the curry's warmth, creating a cozy, inviting mood.

video_script.title: Aloo Mattar: Spiced Potato and Green Peas Curry
video_script.description: Learn how to make Aloo Mattar, a delicious spiced potato and green peas curry that is easy to prepare and full of flavor!

scenes.image_prompt: A vibrant plate of Aloo Mattar garnished with coriander leaves, served with roti and a bowl of yogurt on the side.
scenes.text: Welcome to our Aloo Mattar tutorial!
scenes.voice_over: Today, we are making Aloo Mattar, a flavorful spiced potato and green peas curry, perfect with roti or rice.

scenes.image_prompt: An array of fresh ingredients including potatoes, green peas, onions, and spices neatly arranged on a table.
scenes.voice_over: For Aloo Mattar, you'll need potatoes, green peas, onions, and a variety of spices. Let's take a closer look.

scenes.image_prompt: A pressure cooker with potatoes inside, steam rising from the top.
scenes.voice_over: First, boil the quartered potatoes in a pressure cooker until the first whistle. Cool them in cold water, then peel the skin.

scenes.image_prompt: A bowl with dried green peas soaking in water.
scenes.voice_over: If using dried green peas, soak them for 5 hours, then cook in a pressure cooker until 3 whistles.

scenes.image_prompt: A frying pan with onions sautéing to a golden brown color.
scenes.voice_over: Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan over medium heat. Add chopped onions and fry until they are golden brown.

scenes.image_prompt: A pan filled with onions and chopped tomatoes being stirred together.
scenes.voice_over: Add the chopped tomatoes to the pan and cook until they become mushy and fully integrated with the onions.

scenes.image_prompt: A pan filled with spices, ginger, and onion-tomato mixture being sautéed.
scenes.voice_over: Stir in grated ginger, coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt. Cook for a few minutes until fragrant.

scenes.image_prompt: The cooked potatoes being added to the spice mixture in the pan.
scenes.voice_over: Incorporate the cooked and peeled potatoes, stirring gently. Add water if necessary for desired consistency.

scenes.image_prompt: A pan with both potatoes and green peas mixed together, simmering.
scenes.voice_over: Add the cooked green peas and mix carefully to avoid breaking the potatoes. Let it simmer for a few minutes to blend the flavors.

scenes.image_prompt: A beautifully presented bowl of Aloo Mattar garnished with coriander leaves.
scenes.voice_over: Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves and serve hot with roti, poori, chapati, or paratha.

scenes.image_prompt: The final dish of Aloo Mattar served with various Indian breads and a side of yogurt.
scenes.voice_over: Your Aloo Mattar is ready! Enjoy this delightful dish with family and friends!

cooking_tips: Adjust the heat according to your spice preference by adding more or less chili powder.
For a creamier texture, you can add a splash of coconut milk or yogurt before serving.
